element.name: The Brightest Jewel by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (2/2)

center.font: Visit The Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE

element.long-description:
Can be reached easily from centre city by bus or on foot or cycle. Car parking provided but costs. Free car parking at pub near entrance.
The Multi-Cache:
Don’t be worried about the tree cover which is extensive throughout the gardens. The areas you need to be are all pretty clear so coordinates should not be a great difficulty.
1. Above coordinates take you to a grounded star for info (as I write this in September 06 there is a temporary sculpture series on display at the gardens and the "grounded star" is covered with small stones and an arty representation of "20 Standing Forms". According to it (the star), approx 50 paces north (a couple of hedges are in the way but you get the idea!) to a large Magnolia Acuminata (within an enclosure) with the designation xx 00?36?. Subtract 2 from third figure and use the 6th figure to give you ??
2. At N53 22.336 W006 16.284 You should be standing at a glass door (usually closed). With your back up against the door walk 24 paces SE to a Simaroubacae with the designation xx 013?19. Use missing number.Theme should be clear by now!
3. At N53 22.428 W006 16.289 find Socrates and standing with your back right up against him walk 42 paces SE to a Pinus Nigra with the designation xx ??????. Subtract 12836 from this to give ???
Final coordinates N53 22.answer to 1 and answer to 2 W006 16.answer 3.
National Botanic Gardens
Glasnevin, Dublin 9
Opening Hours
April-Oct Mon-Sat 9.00am-6.00pm
Sunday 10.00am-6.00pm
Nov-Mar Mon-Sun 10.00am-4.30pm
Guided tour is recommended and is available every Sunday at 2.30 free of charge. Otherwise €2 per adult and booking is essential. Phone no. 8570909. Only requirement for the cache is free entry and a stroll around.
“…Our Botanic Establishment is the brightest jewel I am proud to say in the Dublin Society’s cap, admired by all who have visited it”
Dr Walter Wade 3rd May 1819
The National Botanic Gardens are definitely worth a visit for anybody coming to Dublin for the first time. There is a breathtaking variety and quality of plant life both native and otherwise. The gardens were originally laid out from 1795 and they have undergone a series of modifications and improvements up to the present day.
Originally designed for scientific study only, the gardens have developed a worldwide reputation in the development of horticulture. Today they are under the care of The Heritage Service of The Office of Public Works which is implementing The Global Strategy of plant conservation in all its activities.
The present plant population includes approximately 20,000 species and cultivated varieties. There is something to please the botanist, gardener and casual visitor alike. The Rose Garden should always be included in any visit. The Thomas Moore Rose, raised as a cutting from the original plant and immortalized in the ballad “The Last Rose of Summer”, is just west of the Cactus House. The Rhododendron and heather collections and the rockery are always of interest. For indoor folk one of the glass houses contains the giant Amazon water lily. These glass houses themselves, some restored as recently as the late nineties, are worthy of consideration for their fine workmanship.
Finally. some of the finest individual specimens in the Botanic Gardens are trees, e.g. Weeping Cedar, Dwarf Cedar, Purple Beech, Dawn Redwood and Caucasian Elm.
You could spend the day here and not see half of what is on offer.
element.encoded-hints: Corner of building, low behind plants.

ul.li:
2010-05-09T19:00:00Z : Write note by Spark_ie
Unfortunately, Bikes are not allowed inside, and seen as I didn't have a lock on me I had to leave this cache for another time. Pity, because the weather was fantastic today ! [:(]

2010-04-17T19:00:00Z : Found it by Fitzet
Glorious weather in the Botanic Gardens today. We've been here many times before, but never in such good weather, and never with so many crowds.
Locating the first stage was a guess - the 'grounded star' could not be identified, but we were able to get from there to Stage II without a problem. From Stage II, it was plain sailing (apart from our inability to walk in a SE direction) to the cache location, with the help of the hint.
Took : Latvian coin, Grenada keyring Left : Irish 50p coin, Glow in the dark Alien
SL TFTC

2010-04-17T19:00:00Z : Found it by LairdMcHenny
What a beautiful, sunny day! Now is the right time to visit the botanic gardens! highly recommended. THANKS

2010-04-02T16:33:14Z : Found it by daviddotshaw
Found it, nice walk , hard getting to the cache as parking attendant was hovering near by, had to move car so it gave me cover to look for cache.

2010-02-28T20:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
We have found 40 caches this week, and I have to say this is the place I was most impressed with. Possibly because I come from just up the road and although I have been here many times, I haven't been into the actual gardens for many years. What an improvement. The glass houses that were ruins years ago, fully renovated and looking absolutely beautiful. We really enjoyed our stroll around and look forward to returning in the summer to see more growth & colour. It was lovely today, so I'm sure it will be even more beautiful then. Might even take the tour [:D] Thanks for bringing me back here. Had a problem with the first location, searched all around but could find nothing resembling the description [:O], Is it still there? Anyway spotted the magnolias in the enclosure, so carried on from there. TFTC Blue Jay 59 #232

2009-03-17T19:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
Such a beautiful St Paddys' Day so we headed to the gardens. We've been in Dublin for 3 and a half years and this is our first trip. Wish we'd come sooner, the gardens are beautiful. Cache itself was easy to find, if a little tricky to retrieve with the parking attendant muggles watching so closely. TFTC

wpt.name: GCPXEH
wpt.desc: The Brightest Jewel by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (2/2)

Sunday 10.00am-6.00pm
Nov-Mar Mon-Sun 10.00am-4.30pm

Finally. some of the finest individual specimens in the Botanic Gardens are trees, e.g. Weeping Cedar, Dwarf Cedar, Purple Beech, Dawn Redwood and Caucasian Elm.
You could spend the day here and not see half of what is on offer.
